last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18600859
I make soup most Monday mornings, in the winter. Sometimes carrot and coriander like this anon:
>>18603541
Try a little celery in with the onion.
But often variations of:
>Fry some (only 100g or so) cubetti di pancetta (bacon bits, basically) or chorizo
>turn off heat and put pan on something (heatproof) at slight angle, push the pancetta to the top and let the oil drain downhill
>come back to it in five minutes, take out and reserve the pancetta
>use that yummy bacon fat to fry onions, celery, carrot
>add whatever veg I bought (diced). One or two of: brussels, parsnips, cabbage, leeks, cauli, broc and a potato or two to thicken
>sweat for a bit
>maybe make a bouquet garni, depending on what veg
>water and a veg stockpot or cube
>s&p, maybe a small pinch of chilli flakes, cumin or garlic, depending on what veg
>gently simmer for 1/2 hr or so, stirring every ten minutes
>let cool a bit and fish out the bouquet garni if used
>blitz – usually not until smooth, we like some chunks
>chuck the pancetta back in and warm it up at lunchtime
There's usually leftovers for 2 or 3 days that we spread across the week. You don't want the same lunch every day or you'll be bored, no matter how good it is. Cheap, tasty, healthy.

>>18605597
>bread tastes like alcohol
how much of what kind of yeast did you use for how much bread?
>not enough butter, sweetener or salt
what (kind of) bread are you making?
>can I put bread to first-rise in the fridge
yes, but you won't see much of an improvement
proofing is mainly useful to let the gluten network develop, and it might be a bit of a pain to wait hours at a time to de-gas the dough
if you want the bread to smell more like bread letting it ferment for longer is useful, but if you're leaving it in the fridge for the final fermentation you're already getting quite a few esters and other flavorful compounds from the yeast
>am I ruining the bread by using a stand mixer
no, mixers effectively give you the same result as your hands but faster, so the gluten develops a lot more during mixing and the bread doesn't need as much time to proof (say, 2 Vs. 5 times)
notice how, when making bread using the same recipe, the dough is firmer if you mix it with the stand mixer compared to your hands
that's gluten
>should I play with it more
probably not
the crumb's texture and consistency depend on gluten development, to which there's a limit because you only have a finite amount of flour and water
using the stand mixer helps develop the gluten network faster, but the end result is the same as using your hands if you proof the dough long enough, and if you over-mix the dough the gluten will start breaking down, which is undesirable, so unless you want a loaf that's the opposite of chewy try using your hands and only de-gassing the bread 2-3 times, else keep using the mixer

>>18605597
Over-proof can be address by either cut the yeast or cut the time. RN the heaters are on and warm place can get exceptionally warm for overnight proof.
You would know the dough is structurally overproof if the dough is easily or already collapsed.
You can see the trace of that if the lid or plastic film has a skin of dough sticking on the ceiling and rest of the structure collapsed with open foam full of holes, instead of closed foam cells with no holes. Even in situation like this you can push it down, re-ball it and wait an hour and there is sure enough starch in there to puff again.
As for the alcohol smell in finished bread, don't seal your proofing container so tight. Alcohol should naturally evaporate out at slow rate even when overproofed with reasonably breathable containers. Air tight one just hold all the alcohol in, especially when overproof. You will know its too ventilated if the surface of the dough turned into hard scab that can't be mixed in and rehydrated easily. Slight hardening and color darkening is no issue.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18605463
The general rule is "salt as you go". Add an ingredient, add a little salt, add another ingredient, add a little more salt. When whatever you're cooking looks done you taste it, and if it needs a little more salt you add a little more salt. However you do it it's going to take some practice, but looking at an entire pot of beans and just saying, "yeah, I'll just throw in about this much of a handful of salt" is never a good idea. You shouldn't need to measure salt unless you're doing something in very large amounts, or baking.

I'm lacto-fermenting hard-boiled eggs. It's still experimental, haven't tried any yet.
The jar on the left is a week old and contain eggs, watermelon radishes, carrots, onions, red wine vinegar.
The jar on the right I did it today. It contains eggs, onions, celery, garlic, mustard seeds.
I want to wait at least another week before opening a jar. I intend to make a couple jars and stack them to always have eggs at hand.
The brine is 2% salt and water.

The next thing I want to try to ferment is a leftover tomato and meat sauce I have on the stove. In theory, adding brine from another ferment to this sauce after it cooled should inoculate it with Lactobacillus and prevent other organisms from spoiling it and it should last for months.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604452
step one go to japan

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I just had an idea to try all the different hamburger in America. How do I do it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604452
so, you'll have to visit tokyo, osaka, aomori, and hokkaido to do the main ones, but I won't tell you what those are. i will teach you how to order ramen at a real ramen shop in japan, though. first, you need to figure out where the ticket machine is. when you've located it, you need to point at it and loudly declare "MUZU MUZU WAKARIMASEN" over and over again, it's kind of shocking for foreigners but it's a different culture in restaurants in Japan and people typically call out loudly when they need service. one of the ramenyasan will come from behind the counter, you need to hand him your money and say "RAMEN' very clearly or he might just guess and order you fried rice or something. once he's pushed the button to get the ticket, he'll take the ticket back around the counter. now, if the counter is full, the traditional thing is to go stand behind someone who isn't eating quickly enough or otherwise dawdling (using their phone). you need to sigh every few seconds and stage-whisper "OSOI" (pronounced oh-soy). this is part of japanese culture and is how the "many" remind individuals that they are "jama" (in the way). this should shame the patron into leaving. after that, ask for your fork (they'll understand fork) and have at it!

I highly recommend that before your next culinary adventure, be it a filling meal, or even just a light snack, you first shed your clothing, all layers of it!
